articles.headline: Stocks tumble for a third week as jitters over the Fed persist.
articles.snippet: Friday was the S&P 500’s worst day since early March. Recent comments from Fed officials have fueled expectations that interest rates will climb far faster than anyone had thought.
articles.abstract: Friday was the S&P 500’s worst day since early March. Recent comments from Fed officials have fueled expectations that interest rates will climb far faster than anyone had thought.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks slid on Friday, with the S&P 500 capping a third consecutive weekly decline as Wall Street quickly changed its expectation for how aggressively the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates.
articles.byline: By Coral Murphy Marcos

articles.headline: Russians Seize 42 Towns in Eastern Ukraine as Fighting Intensifies
articles.snippet: Ukrainian military officials vowed to reverse Russia’s territorial gains in what was turning into a grinding back-and-forth struggle along a front stretching more than 300 miles.
articles.abstract: Ukrainian military officials vowed to reverse Russia’s territorial gains in what was turning into a grinding back-and-forth struggle along a front stretching more than 300 miles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ukrainian officials acknowledged Friday that Russian forces had taken more than three dozen small towns in their initial drive this week to seize eastern Ukraine, offering the first glimpse of what promises to be a grinding brawl by the Kremlin to achieve broader territorial gains in a new phase of the two-month-old war.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Olmsted’s Enduring Gift
articles.snippet: The man behind many of the nation’s beloved public spaces, Frederick Law Olmsted, was born 200 years ago on April 26. His creations are more essential to modern American life than ever.
articles.abstract: The man behind many of the nation’s beloved public spaces, Frederick Law Olmsted, was born 200 years ago on April 26. His creations are more essential to modern American life than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: The man behind many of the nation’s beloved public spaces, Frederick Law Olmsted, was born 200 years ago on April 26. His creations are more essential to modern American life than ever.
articles.byline: By Ruth Fremson and Audra D. S. Burch

articles.headline: Rattled by Ukraine War, Moldova Strives to Dodge Russia’s Long Shadow
articles.snippet: Moldova’s destiny has been intertwined uncomfortably with Russia’s for years, and the Ukraine invasion has accelerated its efforts to break free from Moscow.
articles.abstract: Moldova’s destiny has been intertwined uncomfortably with Russia’s for years, and the Ukraine invasion has accelerated its efforts to break free from Moscow.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHISINAU, Moldova — Before war erupted next door, Moldovans had big plans for their country.
articles.byline: By Monika Pronczuk and Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: Coach’s Prayers Prompt Supreme Court Test of Religious Freedom
articles.snippet: Joseph Kennedy, a football coach at a public high school in Washington State, lost his job after praying on the 50-yard line after games.
articles.abstract: Joseph Kennedy, a football coach at a public high school in Washington State, lost his job after praying on the 50-yard line after games.
articles.lead_paragraph: BREMERTON, Wash. — Joseph Kennedy, who used to be an assistant coach for a high school football team near Seattle, pointed to the spot on the 50-yard line where he would take a knee and offer prayers after games.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: The End of the All-Male, All-White Cockpit
articles.snippet: Airlines are struggling to find enough pilots and to diversify a profession that has been very resistant to change.
articles.abstract: Airlines are struggling to find enough pilots and to diversify a profession that has been very resistant to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s been a half-century since airlines started hiring women and people of color to fly passenger planes, allowing a handful of pioneering pilots into the flight deck.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: The Former Chancellor Who Became Putin’s Man in Germany
articles.snippet: Gerhard Schröder, who is paid almost $1 million a year by Russian-controlled energy companies, has become a pariah. But he is also a symbol of Germany’s Russia policy.
articles.abstract: Gerhard Schröder, who is paid almost $1 million a year by Russian-controlled energy companies, has become a pariah. But he is also a symbol of Germany’s Russia policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANOVER, Germany — On the evening of Dec. 9, 2005, 17 days after Gerhard Schröder left office as chancellor of Germany, he got a call on his cellphone. It was his friend President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: As Western Arms Pour Into Ukraine, Zelensky Promises Victory
articles.snippet: “The day when they will be forced to leave Ukraine is approaching,” the Ukrainian president said of the Russians, in a sharp change of tone.
articles.abstract: “The day when they will be forced to leave Ukraine is approaching,” the Ukrainian president said of the Russians, in a sharp change of tone.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky, bolstered by an influx of heavy weapons from Western nations, expressed increasing confidence on Saturday that Ukraine was prepared to defeat Russian forces in what is expected to be a long and brutal battle for control of the eastern industrial heartland.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora, Michael Schwirtz and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Inside the Implosion of CNN+
articles.snippet: Seen as the future of CNN, the streaming channel was suddenly killed. Its soon-to-be owner, Discovery, had concerns but until the deal closed, it was constrained in guiding a competitor.
articles.abstract: Seen as the future of CNN, the streaming channel was suddenly killed. Its soon-to-be owner, Discovery, had concerns but until the deal closed, it was constrained in guiding a competitor.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Zaslav had been chief executive of Warner Bros. Discovery for all of a few hours when he learned he had a problem.
articles.byline: By John Koblin, Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: This Man Married a Fictional Character. He’d Like You to Hear Him Out.
articles.snippet: Akihiko Kondo and thousands of others are in devoted fictional relationships, served by a vast industry aimed at satisfying the desires of a fervent fan culture.
articles.abstract: Akihiko Kondo and thousands of others are in devoted fictional relationships, served by a vast industry aimed at satisfying the desires of a fervent fan culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In almost every way, Akihiko Kondo is an ordinary Japanese man. He’s pleasant and easy to talk to. He has friends and a steady job and wears a suit and tie to work.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: With Us or With Them? In a New Cold War, How About Neither.
articles.snippet: Old geopolitical foes are facing off after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but much of the world is refusing to take sides.
articles.abstract: Old geopolitical foes are facing off after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, but much of the world is refusing to take sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — As the bonds of traditional alliances fray across the globe, the Royal Thai Army, the United States’ oldest treaty partner in Asia, has cast a wide net.
articles.byline: By Hannah Beech, Abdi Latif Dahir and Oscar Lopez

articles.headline: In a Ukrainian School, 12 People Await the War’s End, or Their Own
articles.snippet: In the basement of a battered school in Kharkiv, a dozen residents have taken shelter. In a neighborhood not far away, life has returned to some sense of normalcy. But they choose to stay.
articles.abstract: In the basement of a battered school in Kharkiv, a dozen residents have taken shelter. In a neighborhood not far away, life has returned to some sense of normalcy. But they choose to stay.

articles.headline: A Crusade to Challenge the 2020 Election, Blessed by Church Leaders
articles.snippet: Some evangelical pastors are hosting events dedicated to Trump’s election falsehoods and promoting the cause to their congregations.
articles.abstract: Some evangelical pastors are hosting events dedicated to Trump’s election falsehoods and promoting the cause to their congregations.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. — The 11 a.m. service at Church for All Nations, a large nondenominational evangelical church in Colorado’s second-largest city, began as such services usually do. The congregation of young families and older couples swayed and sang along to live music. Mark Cowart, the church’s senior pastor, delivered an update on a church mission project.
articles.byline: By Charles Homans

articles.headline: Emmanuel Macron Defeats Marine Le Pen for Second Term as French President
articles.snippet: The result was a relief to allies in Europe and Washington wary of a far-right challenger who was hostile to the European Union and NATO.
articles.abstract: The result was a relief to allies in Europe and Washington wary of a far-right challenger who was hostile to the European Union and NATO.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Emmanuel Macron won a second term as president of France, triumphing on Sunday over Marine Le Pen, his far-right challenger, after a campaign where his promise of stability prevailed over the temptation of an extremist lurch.
articles.byline: By Roger Cohen

articles.headline: Twitter Nears a Deal to Sell Itself to Elon Musk
articles.snippet: The company’s 11-member board met with Mr. Musk to discuss his offer to buy the social networking service and take it private. An agreement could come as soon as Monday.
articles.abstract: The company’s 11-member board met with Mr. Musk to discuss his offer to buy the social networking service and take it private. An agreement could come as soon as Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Update, 3:05 p.m. Eastern time, April 25: Elon Musk struck a deal to buy Twitter for roughly $44 billion. Follow the latest updates →
articles.byline: By Lauren Hirsch, Mike Isaac and Kate Conger

articles.headline: U.S. Officials Make Top-Secret Visit to Ukraine
articles.snippet: The American government refused to comment on reports that Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had traveled to Ukraine to meet with its leaders.
articles.abstract: The American government refused to comment on reports that Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had traveled to Ukraine to meet with its leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Two top American officials, in a trip shrouded in secrecy, made a wartime journey to Kyiv on Sunday, where President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine planned to urge them to provide more aid in his nation’s battle against Russian invaders, a top Ukrainian official said.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: Warren Buffett Faces Renewed Climate Change Challenge by Investors
articles.snippet: Mr. Buffett has pushed back against investors who want to force Berkshire Hathaway to do more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
articles.abstract: Mr. Buffett has pushed back against investors who want to force Berkshire Hathaway to do more to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors concerned about climate change have developed an effective playbook for getting companies to set more ambitious goals for reducing greenhouse gas emissions by pressuring, shaming and cajoling executives.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Cities Want to Return to Prepandemic Life. One Obstacle: Transit Crime.
articles.snippet: Crime rates on trains and buses are up in some of the nation’s biggest cities, one more barrier for downtowns trying to rebound.
articles.abstract: Crime rates on trains and buses are up in some of the nation’s biggest cities, one more barrier for downtowns trying to rebound.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Sophie Kasakove, Jill Cowan and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: Covid Lockdowns Revive the Ghosts of a Planned Economy
articles.snippet: China is meddling with free enterprise as it hadn’t in decades. The results are familiar to those old enough to remember: scarcity, and the rise of black markets.
articles.abstract: China is meddling with free enterprise as it hadn’t in decades. The results are familiar to those old enough to remember: scarcity, and the rise of black markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yang Wenhui should be a proud example of China’s rise from economic rubble to global powerhouse.
articles.byline: By Li Yuan

articles.headline: Rapid Inflation, Lower Employment: How the U.S. Pandemic Response Measures Up
articles.snippet: The United States spent more on its policy response than other advanced economies. Now economists are revisiting how that worked.
articles.abstract: The United States spent more on its policy response than other advanced economies. Now economists are revisiting how that worked.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States spent more aggressively to protect its economy from the pandemic than many global peers, a strategy that has helped to foment more rapid inflation — but also a faster economic rebound and brisk job gains.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Twitter Employees Search for Answers as Musk Takeover Becomes Reality
articles.snippet: Workers say they have been left largely in the dark about what a sale to the billionaire will mean for them and their shares in the company.
articles.abstract: Workers say they have been left largely in the dark about what a sale to the billionaire will mean for them and their shares in the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: In January 2020, thousands of Twitter employees gathered in Houston for a corporate summit called #OneTeam. During the event, Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief executive at the time, revealed he had invited a surprise guest. Then, with a wave and a smile, Elon Musk appeared on giant screens above the stage. The crowd cheered, clapped and pumped fists. “We love you,” one employee shouted.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger
